awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Transforming the Organic Chemistry Lab Experience: Implementation and Evaluation of a Reformed Organic Lab Curriculum Across Institutions
awd_abstract_narration:
Organic chemistry is required for college students majoring in a variety of STEM disciplines. Traditionally, this course has been viewed as a gatekeeper and students have considered the laboratory experience as an isolated and irrelevant use of their time. Reformed teaching methods that increase the relevance of the laboratory and increase student success have proven challenging to deliver, especially when laboratories are taught by graduate teaching assistants. This project, which builds on prior NSF-funded work (DUE Awards #1245160 and #1245176), will develop, implement, and study innovative and easy-to-adopt studio-based organic lab modules. These modules will transform the traditional 3-4 hour organic laboratory into a meaningful learning experience involving trouble-shooting problems and honing lab skills. The project is a collaborative effort between a research university (Rochester Institute of Technology) and a community college (Monroe Community College), which will ensure the materials are appropriate for use in both two-year and four-year settings. In collaboration with regional partners, studies will be conducted to evaluate student learning in other settings, as well as the ease of module adoption, student performance, and retention rates.

This project leverages earlier work developing a studio-based organic laboratory curriculum for two-year and four-year colleges, and promoting its broadened development and implementation. Central goals of the project are enhancing students' meaningful learning and engagement with organic chemistry, and developing a model for implementation of reform-based curricula. To determine the impact of this approach, the project will measure student learning and success, and evaluate the ease and fidelity of module adoption at collaborating institutions. Given the diverse population of students across the institutions committed to adopt the materials and the proximity to the National Technical Institute for the Deaf, further studies will identify retention trends for a diverse set of student populations. This will contribute to developing a more diverse, globally competitive STEM workforce. The results will be disseminated broadly via a PI-sponsored conference, peer-reviewed publications, conference presentations, a website, and a textbook partnership.

por.por_cntn:
The project was intended to broaden the implementation of, and further develop, Reformed Experimental Activities (REActivities) for use in an organic chemistry lab curriculum at both 2-year and 4-year colleges. REActivities are uniquely delivered labs that philosophically mirror a guided-inquiry approach.  This easy-to-adopt pedagogy was designed to transform the commonplace 3-4 hour organic lab periods into impactful opportunities for students to engage with their peers and instructor, all while honing new lab skills. To determine the efficacy of the approach, studies were conducted to evaluate transferability, transportability, student performance, and barriers to adoption.

What follows are the major outcomes from the life of this project:

  • A LOPUS-inspired observational instrument - called Evaluation of Lab Instructor Time and Engagement (ELITE) ? was created to gauge the fidelity of implementation when REActivities are adopted across various institutions and with different instructors. Data from an expert instructor of the pedagogy was determined to be extremely comparable with new adopters. Additionally, when the behaviors of instructors using REActivities were compared with those not using REActivities, a noticeable increase in the amount of lecture time was observed for traditional (expository) labs, while lecture time was near zero when REActivities were used. Additionally, when instructors engaged with students during REActivities, 30% of that engagement consistently involved discussions coded as conceptual in nature. This is in stark contrast to nearly zero conceptual discussions coded when instructors taught using traditional methods.
  • The Meaningful Learning in the Lab (MLLI) instrument was utilized to measure the student-reported learning gains when using REActivities. The results of this analysis have shown positive trends longitudinally from first-semester organic chemistry lab to second-semester organic chemistry lab. The greatest difference was observed for questions coded in the affective domain (how a student feels). Overall, this leads to a conclusion that students are more confident over time when using REActivities; this is informing future qualitative studies.  
  • Sign Language Incorporation in Chemistry Education (SLICE) was the result of further development of REActivities. Specifically, a sign language lexicon in organic chemistry and its impact on Deaf students in the course was developed. Videos were created to inform both Deaf and hearing students about the signs specific to transition state modeling and accompanying REActivities were created to guide students through the incorporation of these signs. This work showed significantly improved performance trends for Deaf students over the course of three years when adopting these signs.
  • Covid-19 forced the team to explore alternative approaches to the delivery of REActivities during the pandemic. As a result, a virtual lab experience was created for each REActivity. These videos were shared on both the REActivities website: www.reactivities.org and on a dedicated YouTube channel www.youtube.com/c/reactivities. These videos supported many faculty seeking online learning materials during the pandemic. With labs back to an in-person format, these impactful videos are now serving as pre-lab preparations, post-lab reviews, and instructor training tutorials.

The project?s findings were guided by an external evaluator in year three of the award. A total of seven universities were involved in the data collection and study. The investigators hope to expand this work toward other lab-based disciplines.
